chapter.htmlHeader: Scenario: Compression stockings
chapter.summary: Covers the use of compression stockings in the management of venous disease affecting the legs.
chapter.htmlStringContent: From age 16 years onwards.

chapters.fullItemName: Have I got the right topic?

subChapters.htmlHeader: What assessment should I carry out before prescribing compression stockings?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Take a detailed medical and surgical history and ask about:
    • Previous limb trauma and infection.
    • Concurrent illnesses.
    • Medication (for example, corticosteroids).
    • Family history of venous disease. 
    • Risk factors for venous disease (for example, previous limb surgery, deep vein thrombosis).
  • Assess the person's legs for:
    • Signs of venous disease: varicose veins, venous dermatitis, haemosiderin deposition, lipodermatosclerosis and atrophie blanche. 
    • Oedema, and exclude non-venous causes.
    • For more information, see the sections on assessment in the CKS topics on Leg ulcer - venous,  Varicose veins and Venous eczema and lipodermatosclerosis.
  • Exclude arterial insufficiency.
    • Measure the ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) in both legs using a Doppler machine. It is the ratio of the ankle to the brachial systolic pressure. If the ABPI is:
      • Less than 0.8 — compression stockings are contraindicated, as severe arterial insufficiency is likely. Refer the person for specialist vascular assessment.
      • Between 0.8 and 1.3 — compression stockings are safe to wear.
      • Greater than 1.3 — avoid compression, as high ABPI values may be due to calcified and incompressible arteries. Refer the person for specialist vascular assessment.
  • Check the condition of the skin:
    • Fragile skin may be damaged while trying to put on or take off compression stockings.
    • Ideally, venous ulcers should be healed before using compression stockings.
  • Consider whether the person is likely to be able to manage compression stockings:
    • Mobility and dexterity may be reduced in some people (for example older people, people with arthritis), which may make it difficult for the person to put on or take off stockings.
    • If the person is likely to have difficulty, an application aid may be helpful, or support from community nursing staff may be needed.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) guideline Management of chronic venous leg ulcers [SIGN, 2010], the Wounds UK Best practice statement: Compression hosiery [Wounds UK, 2015], expert opinion in a consensus document Simplifying venous leg ulcer management [Harding, 2015], and narrative reviews The assessment, selection and benefits of made-to-measure hosiery [JCN, 2015] and Selecting compression hosiery [Todd, 2015].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How do I decide on the strength of compression?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• The recommended degree of compression (class of stocking) depends on the condition being treated, but should be the highest the person can tolerate.
    • Varicose veins — class 1 or 2 stockings, depending on the severity of the varicose veins and tolerability. For more information, see the CKS topic on Varicose veins.
    • Venous eczema, lipodermatosclerosis, atrophie blanche, healed venous leg ulcers — class 2 stockings. 
      • Try class 3 stockings if response to class 2 stockings is inadequate.
      • Try class 1 stockings if class 2 are not tolerated. 
      • For more information, see the CKS topic on Venous eczema and lipodermatosclerosis.
    • After deep vein thrombosis (DVT) for the prevention of post-thrombotic syndrome — do not offer elastic graduated compression stockings to prevent post-thrombotic syndrome or venous thromboembolism (VTE) recurrence after a proximal DVT.
      • This recommendation does not cover the use of elastic stockings for the management of leg symptoms after DVT. 
      • For more information, see the CKS topic on Deep vein thrombosis.
    • Superficial thrombophlebitis — class 2 stockings.
      • Most people find class 2 stockings too painful, class 1 stockings or travel socks are practical alternatives.
      • For more information, see the CKS topic on Thrombophlebitis - superficial.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• The recommendation that the highest acceptable compression should be used is based on the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) guideline Management of chronic venous leg ulcers [SIGN, 2010] and expert opinion in a narrative review Optimising concordance with compression hosiery in the community setting [Anderson, 2015].
  • For evidence on the use of compression stockings in venous disorders, see the CKS topic on the specific condition being treated.

subChapters.fullItemName: Choice between below knee and thigh length
subChapters.htmlHeader: How do I choose between below knee and thigh length?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Therapy with compression stockings may be lifelong, so compliance is important. The choice of stocking length should be determined by the person's preference. 
  • Below-knee compression stockings are recommended:
    • To prevent recurrence of venous leg ulcer in patients where leg ulcer healing has been achieved.
    • When swelling is limited to the lower leg, or if use of thigh-length stockings is not possible or desirable.
  • Consider thigh-length stockings in people with severe varicose veins above the knee or who have swelling which extends above the knee.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) guideline Management of chronic venous leg ulcers [SIGN, 2010], a U.S guideline Management of venous leg ulcers: Clinical practice guidelines of the Society for Vascular Surgery and the American Venous Forum [O'Donnell, 2014], the British Medical Journal (BMJ) best practice guide Chronic venous insufficiency [BMJ, 2017], and expert opinion in a narrative review Selecting compression hosiery [Todd, 2015].

  • There is no evidence that one type of compression, duration, or stocking length is more efficacious than any other in prevention of venous disease [O'Donnell, 2014].
  • A randomised controlled trial, comparing thigh-length with below-knee compression stockings for the prevention of post-thrombotic syndrome, found that thigh-length stockings do not offer better protection against post-thrombotic syndrome than below-knee stockings, and they are less well tolerated [BMJ, 2017].
  • An estimated 30–65% of people are non-compliant with compression therapy [BMJ, 2017].
    • CKS recommends that on this basis, the choice of stocking length should be decided by the person's preference in order to aid compliance.

subChapters.fullItemName: Choice between open and closed toe
subChapters.htmlHeader: How do I choose between open and closed toe?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• The choice of open or closed toe stocking mainly depends on the person's preference.
  • Open toe stockings may be preferred for people who:
    • Have arthritic or clawed toes, or fungal infection.
    • Prefer to wear a sock over the compression stocking.
    • Have a long foot size compared with their calf size.
  • Advantages of open-toe stockings include: 
    • They are slightly easier to apply.
    • They may be cooler in hot weather.
  • Disadvantages of open-toe stockings include:
    • They can exacerbate painful foot joints.
    • They are more likely to ride up the foot and cause toe swelling.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the Wounds UK Best practice statement: Compression hosiery [Wounds UK, 2015], and expert opinion in a narrative review Selecting compression hosiery [Todd, 2015].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How do I ensure that the stocking fits the person correctly?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Compression stockings are available in several ready-made sizes — the choice is determined by measuring the person's leg.
    • This can be undertaken in the pharmacy (a payment can be claimed for this service when dispensing a prescription for compression stockings).
    • If this is not possible, the person or their carer may be asked to take the measurements (if capable) or the person should be referred back to the prescriber for alternative arrangements to be made.
  • If stockings are to be worn on both legs, measure each leg to exclude a significant discrepancy in size (in which case, two differently sized stockings will need to be ordered).
  • Measurements that need to be taken vary depending on the stocking manufacturer, but in general the following need to be obtained for below-knee stockings (taken with the person seated, and feet flat on the floor):
    • Circumference of the ankle, at the narrowest point just above the ankle bone (malleoli).
    • Circumference of the widest part of the calf (usually the mid-calf area).
    • Length of the foot from the heel to the tip of the longest toe (if a closed-toe stocking is required).
  • If a thigh-length stocking is prescribed, also measure around the widest part of the thigh.
  • If the person has a swollen leg, measurements should be taken first thing in the morning — this may require a visit by a community nurse.
  • Severely swollen legs may first require a period of compression bandaging.
  • Made-to-measure stockings may be required if the person has a deformity affecting the leg or if a correctly sized ready-made stocking cannot be obtained from leg measurements.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the Wounds UK Best practice statement: Compression hosiery [Wounds UK, 2015], and what CKS considers good practice.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How do I prescribe made-to-measure stockings, if these are required?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• State 'made to measure' on the prescription.
    • NOTE: If a pharmacist, on measuring a person for ready-made stockings identifies that a made to measure stocking is required, they can endorse the prescription with 'made to measure' and be reimbursed appropriately.
  • The pharmacist will complete a manufacturer's order form, which will specify the measurements required. If the pharmacist cannot take the measurements (for example the person is unable to attend the pharmacy), a member of the primary healthcare team may need to measure the person.
  • As with ready-made stockings, if the leg is swollen, measurements are best taken first thing in the morning or after a period of compression bandaging.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the Wounds UK Best practice statement: Compression hosiery [Wounds UK, 2015], the Prescription Pricing Authority (PPA) Drug tariff [Prescription Pricing Authority, 2017], and what CKS consider good practice.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Should stockings be removed at bedtime?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Compression stockings should generally be taken off at bedtime and put back on first thing in the morning (before any leg swelling develops or worsens).
  • If this is not possible, they can be worn continuously for up to a maximum of 7 days.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) guideline Management of chronic venous leg ulcers [SIGN, 2010], and the Wounds UK Best practice statement: Compression hosiery [Wounds UK, 2015].

subChapters.htmlHeader: How often should stockings be replaced?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Compression stockings should be replaced every 3–6 months.
  • Provide at least two stockings (or two pairs if used on both legs), so that one can be worn while the other is being washed and dried.
  • The stocking should be replaced earlier if any defects or damage become apparent or if on stretching, the stocking does not return to its original shape.
  • Ideally, each time a stocking is replaced, the leg should be re-measured.
  • The life of the stocking can be prolonged by correct washing. Stockings should be hand washed at about 40°C (a comfortable hand temperature) and dried away from direct heat.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the Scottish Intercollegiate Guidelines Network (SIGN) guideline Management of chronic venous leg ulcers [SIGN, 2010], the Wounds UK Best practice statement: Compression hosiery [Wounds UK, 2015], information from the NHS Choices website, a manufacturer's product leaflet, and what CKS considers good practice.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How frequently should a person be reviewed?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Review every 3–6 months to:
    • Reassess the condition for which the stocking is being prescribed.
    • Ensure that the person is continuing to wear the stocking successfully and is replacing them regularly.
    • Repeat leg measurements to ensure that the stocking continues to be the correct size.
  • Ideally, Doppler studies should be repeated every 6–12 months or earlier if clinically indicated. Follow local policies, if available.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
These recommendations are based on the Royal College of Nursing (RCN) guideline The nursing management of patients with venous leg ulcers [RCN, 2006], expert opinion in a narrative review How to select the best compression hosiery for your patient [JCN, 2014], the Wounds UK Best practice statement: Compression hosiery [Wounds UK, 2015], and what CKS considers good practice.

  • Arterial disease may develop in people with venous disease, and significant reductions in ankle-brachial pressure index can occur over a relatively short period (3–12 months) [RCN, 2006].
    • In practice, the frequency of Doppler assessment will be guided by local availability and resources.

subChapters.htmlHeader: How can I encourage compliance with wearing stockings?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
• Ensure that the person understands the reasons for, and the benefits of, wearing compression stockings.
  • Ensure that the person has been shown how to put on and take off the stocking and that they are able to do so.  
    • If the person is having difficulty, an application aid may be prescribed (for example, ActiGlide®).
    • Explain that the best time to put stockings on is first thing in the morning, before any leg swelling develops.
  • Check that the person is happy with the colour of the stocking.
    • Men may prefer black or other colours, rather than flesh coloured.
  • Ensure that the stocking is a correct fit — if standard sizes are not suitable, the person may need a made-to-measure stocking.
  • If the person is having difficulty tolerating the level of compression, try a lighter compression stocking.
  • If the person is having difficulty using a thigh-length stocking, consider switching to a below-knee stocking (thigh-length stockings are not usually necessary).
  • Explain that the stocking should be taken off at bedtime.
    • Recommend application of an emollient while the stocking is off, to reduce skin dryness and irritation.
  • Explain the importance of a regular review and replacement of stockings to ensure they continue to fit well and provide the correct level of compression.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent: These recommendations are based on the Wounds UK Best practice statement: Compression hosiery [Wounds UK, 2015], and what CKS considers good practice.
